headline: Hilton Worldwide Holdings (NYSE:HLT) Sees First Quarter Revenue Increase Despite Lower Sales
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings (NYSE:HLT) reported promising first-quarter results and optimistic earnings guidance for 2025, likely impacting its notable share price move of 8% over the past week. The company's quarterly revenue and net income growth, coupled with a strategic expansion in Costa Rica, underscore its robust position in the luxury market. This gain aligns with a broader market positive trend, as major indices such as the Dow and S&P 500 extended their winning streaks, buoyed by...

headline: Hims & Hers with Novo Nordisk, Hilton, PayPal: Trending Tickers
summary: Morning Brief co-hosts Brad Smith and Madison Mills examine today's trending tickers. Hims & Hers (HIMS) partners with Novo Nordisk (NOVO-B.CO, NVO) to offer customers bundled weight-loss treatments. Hilton (HLT) reports strong earnings growth for the first quarter but lowered its full-year per-room sales forecast. PayPal (PYPL) announces mixed first quarter results, but reaffirms its outlook. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Hilton Posts Profit Growth, Boosts 2025 Earnings View on Solid Demand
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings posted first-quarter net income growth and boosted its projection for adjusted 2025 earnings as the hotelier shrugged off what it called weaker macroeconomic conditions.

headline: Hilton (NYSE:HLT) Reports Sales Below Analyst Estimates In Q1 Earnings
summary: Hotel company Hilton (NYSE:HLT) fell short of the market’s revenue expectations in Q1 CY2025 as sales rose 4.7% year on year to $2.70 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.72 per share was 7% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

raw.headline: Hilton (NYSE:HLT) Reports Sales Below Analyst Estimates In Q1 Earnings

headline: Hilton cuts 2025 revenue growth forecast as travel demand softens
summary: American consumers are growing cautious about discretionary spending such as travel, after President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs and the resulting trade war sparked fears of an economic recession.  Earlier this month, legacy US carriers Delta Air Lines, Southwest, and American pulled their financial forecast for 2025.
